utterances: ...Where you're talking to a woman who we assume is your boyfriend's ex.
(Singing) I know you feel he may be comin' back to you.
He won't, he won't, he won't, won't.
I know you feel like he'll come around.
Is there New Orleans in that?
And they say, you know, something about them New Orleans girls.
Because there's a level of strength - right?
- in us that is, I wouldn't say arrogant.
No matter where we come from - we don't need money - we hold ourself at a standard.
The women that I knew from New Orleans, the women that walked like they - they'd talk like that.
Like, that's how I want to walk in my relationship.
And I know a lot of people out there who understand that.
I know a lot of women who relate to the idea of being unapologetically open about saying, no, I'm not accepting anything but this because I am worth it.
And I wanted to make an album that spoke to those things.
(Singing) And even though we're broken, that don't mean we ain't diamonds.
Her new album, ""New Breed,"" is just out.
And it's May 1, May Day, which, depending on how you celebrate, means workers protesting in the streets or dancing around a maypole.
If there's one thing that can bring us all together though, it's the puzzle.
Joining me now is Will Shortz, puzzle editor of The New York Times and WEEKEND EDITION's puzzle master.
And remind us of last week's challenge.
Yes, I said name a famous singer, first and last names.
The last four letters of the first name spelled backward plus the first four letters of the last name spelled forward read together in order name a section of products in a drugstore.
Well, the singer is Mariah Carey, and that section is the hair care section.
And our randomly selected winner is Ryan McNeill of Watkinsville, Ga.
Big Mariah Carey fan, are you?
It came quickly to you, this one?
And I struggle with so many of these things but this one...
I - there's too many singers to think of.
So I pictured walking through a pharmacy and...
The aisle - nd so I thought, you know, skin care came into my head.
And then there's how it goes.
And what's life like down in Watkinsville?
Obviously it's the Deep South, so it's already getting pretty warm here.
And what do you do down there?
So I work for the University of Georgia, and I manage a horticulture research farm.
What does that mean in practice?
So it's a 90-acre farm, and we support research in the horticulture department for the university.
So we got your traditional southern crops like pecans and peaches and blueberries.
And I suppose - I mean, that's all for students who are learning how to grow things so...
That's right - students and professors conducting research.
So you ready to play the puzzle?
